New Records: The contest was the first MLB postseason match-up between two Japanese-born starting pitchers.
Key Match Events: Yoshinobu Yamamoto pitched five brilliant innings, giving up two hits with one walk and two strikeouts.
Enrique Hernandez hit a solo home run in the second inning.
Teoscar Hernandez hit a 420-foot solo home run in the seventh inning.
The Dodgers' relievers closed out the game without allowing a hit over four innings.
The Padres' hitters combined to go 1-for-14 at the plate in Game 5.
The Padres failed to score a run in the last 24 innings of the series.
Pre-Game Insights: Yoshinobu Yamamoto was determined to improve on a lackluster performance in the Dodgers' Game 1 win.
Dodgers manager Dave Roberts was confident Yamamoto would rise to the occasion based on his past performances.
Post-Match Reflections: Dodgers manager Dave Roberts praised Yamamoto's performance, stating he set the tone for the game.
Padres manager Mike Shildt found little to fault in Yu Darvish's performance, stating he was magnificent.
Shildt described the Padres' scoring drought as 'stunning'.
Shohei Ohtani expressed excitement about the atmosphere and his opportunity to battle for a World Series berth.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The Dodgers advanced to the National League Championship Series for the first time since 2021.
Shohei Ohtani went hitless in four at-bats in Game 5.
Ohtani is in the playoffs for the first time after joining the Dodgers in December in a record 10-year, $700 million deal.
